description: Cecile G. Tamura Mary Somerville was the first person to be called a ‚Äúscientist.‚Äù   She was a self-taught polymath who tutored Ada Lovelace:  http://bit.ly/2B7Z5pd    A high art of connecting the seemingly disconnected.  "In 1834, the Cambridge don William Whewell wrote a complimentary article about Mary Somerville, a Scottish researcher whose erudite books brought together previously disparate fields of mathematics, astronomy, geology, chemistry, and physics so clearly that the texts became the backbone of Cambridge University‚Äôs first science curriculum. He called Somerville a scientist, in part because ‚Äúman of science‚Äù seemed inappropriate for a woman, but more significantly because Somerville‚Äôs work was interdisciplinary. She was no mere astronomer, physicist, or chemist, but a visionary thinker who articulated the connections among the various branches of inquiry."   https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mary_Somerville     https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7OjuLSG7_ks

description: Cecile G. Tamura "It‚Äôs not inconceivable to think that in a 20-year time frame everything in a cell phone could be put into your head in a minimally invasive way."  Transcending the cognitive and physical limitations previous generations of humankind have taken for granted.   # bioengineering   # braincomputerinterface   # fluidneuralintegration   # patternrecognition   # neuroscience   # neurosurgery  At the top of the list of things to do is preparing humanity for what's coming.  It‚Äôs ‚Äúvery, very obvious‚Äù that in the next five to 10 years some form of brain-computer interface will be used to rehabilitate victims of strokes, spinal cord injuries, chronic pain, and other disorders. The current recording techniques are comparable to the IBM computers of the 1960s, saying that they are now ‚Äúarchaic.‚Äù  For the technology to reach its true long-term potential a new sort of brain-scanning technology will be needed‚Äîsomething that can read far more neurons at once.

description: Cecile G. Tamura Synthetic organisms : how far can life be redesigned?  Could life have evolved differently? A germ with ‚Äúunnatural‚Äù DNA letters suggests the answer is yes.  ‚ÄúLife as we know it is may not be the only solution, and may not be the best one.‚Äù  Every living thing on Earth stores the instructions for life as DNA, using the four genetic bases A, G, C, and T.  All except one, that is.  In the San Diego laboratory of Floyd Romesberg‚Äîand at a startup he founded‚Äîgrow bacteria with an expanded genetic code. They have two more letters, an ‚Äúunnatural‚Äù pair he calls X and Y.  The practical payoff of an organism with a bigger genetic alphabet is that it has a bigger vocabulary‚Äîit can assemble proteins with components not normally found in nature. That could solve some tricky problems in medicinal chemistry, which is the art of shaping molecules so they do exactly what‚Äôs wanted in the body, and nothing that isn‚Äôt.  Another ethical crossroad. Nathalie Cabrol Seth Shostak
